Hello,

I am new to this forum and stumbled lately upon the NEAT-idea. On t=
he
same day I found HyperNeat. And as I am a c# developer I want to use
Hyp=
erSharpNeat.

Regarding this one I have some initial questions. Maybe someb=
ody has
time to answer some of these questions.

1) To create a new experim=
ent I only need to implement classes with
the interfaces IExperiment, INetw=
orkEvaluator,
MultiThreadedPopulationEvaluator (here I can just use the bas=
e method
as demonstrated in Skirmish experiment). Am I right?
Can I also us=
e the base Substrate class or will I need to create my
own? I want to give =
my networks the possibilities to use different
activation functions. That's=
 what the substrate class is for, am I right?

2) Calling MultipleSteps(n).=
 Let's say I have a network with 1 input,
1 output and 2 hidden layers. Cal=
ling SingleStep / MultipleSteps(1) I
asume, that the values from the input =
layer will be propagated to the
first hidden layer. The values from the fir=
st hidden layer to the
second and the second hidden layer values to the out=
put layer. So I
would need to call MultipleSteps(3) / MultipleSteps(1+
Numb=
erOfHiddenLayers) till the input values reached the output. Is
this correct=
? Why is there a need to set this value. Is it not
possible to just do so m=
any steps till the input reached the output?
Maybe I am also misunderstandi=
ng things here.

3) Activation functions: I want to give the network all ac=
tivation
functions that are possible so it has more to choose from. Hyperbo=
lic
tangent is one mainly used activation function used in normal
perceptio=
n networks. Is there a reason that it is not available. Or is
it obsolete d=
ue to an other function that is taking this place? Or
shall I add it? 

4) =
Maybe you can also help me out on this, too. I have much binary
inputs and =
outputs. Should I just use (0 / 1) or convert it to (0 /
0.5) or
(-0.5 / 0.=
5). Do you have experiences on here?

Thank you very much for your answers =
in advance!

Kind regards,

Christian
